title: SSC Gets World Cup Fever
summary:
Key ideas
- The World Cup has overly complicated advancement procedures.
- The author wonders if these procedures could create a primitive neural net.
- The payoff matrix heavily penalizes losing over tying and winning over tying.
- Both teams may benefit from establishing a mutually beneficial equilibrium of not scoring goals.

Key learnings
- The World Cup has weird incentive structures.
- The author enjoys following these complicated procedures.
- Teams may benefit from communicating to establish mutually beneficial equilibrium.
- The establishment of a government to enforce a Platonic social contract and virtuous behavior is a solution to incentive problems.

Key questions
- How complicated do the advancement rules have to be before the tournament acts as a sort of primitive neural net?
- Could a sufficiently large soccer tournament achieve sentience and feel suffering?
- Can both teams establish a mutually beneficial equilibrium of not scoring goals?
- Can such a plan be enforced against the temptation to defect and score a goal at the last second for national glory?
